editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: ANALECTS IN VERSE AND PROSE, CHIEFLY DRAMATICAL, SATIRICAL, AND PASTORAL.
LONDON: PRINTED FOR P. SHATWELL, OPPOSITE DURHAM-YARD IN THE STRAND; J. DODSLEY, PALL-MALL; AND T. DAVIES, RUSSEL-STREET, COVENT-GARDEN. MDCCLXX.

div.head: TO CHARLES DUNSTER, ESQ. OF ORIEL COLLEGE, OXFORD.
div.p:
THE indefatigable means you took to convince me of your friendſhip, by promoting the following trifles, made me take the liberty of inſcribing them to you; for indeed, I had ſcarce hinted my intention, when you took the earlieſt opportunity of procuring thoſe eſſentials, which have proved the means of my bringing them to light; I am perfectly convinced, that you have humanity enough to overlook the too many imperfections
you will meet with, if you ſhou'd have patience enough to read my little Analects; for from my connections in buſineſs, and the attention that I am, from an innate affection, oblig'd to pay my fire-ſide, have made me, in ſome meaſure, more inattentive, than I ſhould have been; I have inſerted many, I could have wiſh'd to eraſe; becauſe I had not time to finiſh many pieces which I had begun; and indeed, I was out in my calculation, in what would furniſh a couple of volumes, but yet determined, not to extend it in appearance; I mean, not as is generally done on theſe occaſions, to give much paper and little printing; I often wiſh'd to have found you at my elbow, when I have ſent a proof to preſs, that you might have given a poliſh to the many rude, and uncultivated paſſages I am afraid you will ſtammer at.—However, I ſhall truſt to your candour and good ſenſe, to make ſuch allowances, as you ſhall think neceſſary; and when I ſee you, I am ſure you will ſhew ſo much the gentleman, as to whiſper my errors to me, that no aſſiduous critic may know there is a fault, through you, when he has not capacity enough to find it out himſelf.—But this is rather unneceſſary, as I am ſo circumſtantially
convinced of your friendſhip and eſteem; for I always perceived, on thoſe occaſions, that you ſeemed happy, rather to throw a veil over an error in your friend, than expoſe it to the greedy ear of envy, for the ſake of ſelf-oſtentation, or the elevating plaudits of a ſelect ſociety.

I was once in hopes, that the Nut-brown Maid would have made its appearance on the the ſtage, but Mr. GARRICK gave me ſo many ſufficient reaſons why it would not do, (not altogether diveſting it of merit) that I reſign'd my hopes with pleaſure, knowing, from the many material marks of friendſhip I have experienced from that gentleman, if it had been perfectly calculated, he would have given it the faireſt chance in his power; therefore I printed it, hoping it might afford ſome little entertainment in the cloſet. You was pleaſed ſome time ago to ſend me a few corrections you had made, in what I had given you to look over, but by ſome accident or other, I had the misfortune to loſe them, which was of no little concern to me, as what they were, have eſcaped my remembrance, ſo that at leaſt I am convinced, you will meet with the ſame errors
again; whence I thought it neceſſary to give you ſome reaſon, why I have not adhered to your amendments; but if ever a future opportunity ſhould offer, on the like occaſion, I will endeavour to be more careful.

closer.signed: I am, with the greateſt reſpect and ſincerity, your moſt obliged, and humble ſervant, GEORGE SAVILLE CAREY.

div.head: ACT I.
SCENE I.
div.stage: A Grove, with a proſpect behind of a fine rural country; Emma, diſguiſed as a Sheperdeſs, ſitting on a green bank under a tree; the curtain drawing up with ſoft muſic, and Emma ſings as ſhe ſits on the back of the ſtage.

lg.l: YE ſecret ſhades, ye verdant plains,
Where peace her gentle ſway maintains,
Whilſt round her fair and tranquil throne,
No ſighs are heard, no tears are ſhown;
But love and ſweet content are ſeen,
And ev'ry face appears ſerene;
O let a maiden join thy train,
'Till happy with her baniſh'd ſwain.

div.head: SCENE II.
div.stage: Enter Allan and Robin, liſtening to her ſinging.

sp.speaker: Allan.
sp.p: She is ſomewhere here about, I'm ſure.

sp.speaker: Robin.
sp.p: And yonder ſhe ſits.

sp.speaker: Allan.
sp.p: 'Slife, and ſo ſhe does, and a charming laſs ſhe is—Egad I'll to her.

sp.speaker: Robin.
sp.p: Hold man, perhaps 'tis a fairy.

sp.speaker: Allan.
sp.p: If ſhe be, I don't care; I muſt change a word or two, be what ſhe will.

sp.speaker: Robin.
sp.p: You may if you pleaſe, for I go no further.

sp.speaker: Allan.
sp.p: She's fleſh and blood I ſee by her ſteps: he that would run away from ſuch a fairy ought never to ſee ſuch another—pray, pretty maid, are you married?—hey! not ſpeak?—hum, I dad, ſhe's ſulky methinks?—what may ſhe want now?—hum, an huſband I warrant; or perhaps ſhe has got one, and wants to be rid of 'm.

sp.speaker: Robin.
sp.p: That is to ſay, ſhe is either married againſt her will, or 'tis againſt her will ſhe is not married.

sp.speaker: Allan.
sp.p: Pray, young woman, be'ant you well.

sp.speaker: Emma.
sp.p: No indeed, yet I ſhould be much better if you would do me one favour.

sp.speaker: Robin and Allen.
sp.p: Aye, that we will, any thing you ſhall ſay.

sp.speaker: Emma.
sp.p: But you will be ſure, both of you, to keep your words.

sp.speaker: Allan.
sp.p: Never doubt it, ſweetheart, never doubt it.

sp.speaker: Emma.
sp.p: Then you cannot do any thing that will pleaſe me more than to take yourſelves away.

sp.speaker: Robin.
sp.p: Oh, oh, ſhe can ſpeak you find.

sp.speaker: Allan.
sp.p: Wounds, ſhe's 'ſtound me.

sp.speaker: Emma.
sp.p: Why are ye not gone?

sp.speaker: Robin.
sp.p: Aye, aye, come along; troth if you don't I'll tell Sue.

sp.speaker: Allan.
sp.p: I don't care for that neither; I muſt break my word for once.

lg.head: SONG.
lg.l: Say, ſay, what you will,
I'll tarry here ſtill,
My heart is entrapp'd in a ſnare;
Go, go, and tell Sue,
You've nought elſe to do,
But ſtay here I will, I declare.

sp.speaker: Emma.
sp.p: Aye, prithee do, and you'll do well.

sp.speaker: Allan.
sp.p: Edad then I'll follow, go where you will, my laſs.

sp.speaker: Emma.
sp.p: You had better go follow the plough.

sp.speaker: Allan.
sp.p: Nay, nay, now, thou doſt'nt think ſo, I am ſure: come let us be better acquainted.

sp.speaker: Emma.
sp.p: Prithee, clod, begone; for thou'lt make thyſelf as hateful to me as thou art troubleſome.

lg.head: SONG.
lg.l: Hence, away, thou hateful clown,
Thou ſilly blockhead, hence:
Go ſeek ſome bumkin of thy own,
Like thee unknown to ſenſe.

sp.speaker: Allan.
sp.p: Who could have thought ſo pretty a creature could have been in ſuch a paſſion.

sp.speaker: Robin.
sp.p: Aye, ſhe's a trimmer I warrant ye; there's many a fair face with a foul tongue they ſay; you had better ſtick to poor Sue, if ſhe knew you was here ſhe would be breaking her heart I ſuppoſe.

sp.speaker: Allan.
sp.p:
There's no harm, man, in having two
ſtrings to one's bow; for when one is too full of her airs I like to have another to fly to.

sp.speaker: Robin.
sp.p: And yet you are mightily mift too when Sue happens to ſmile at any body but yourſelf.
sp.stage: [Huntſmen and horns heard at a diſtance.

sp.speaker: Allan.
sp.p: Hark! the hounds.

sp.speaker: Robin.
sp.p: I' dad ſo there are, [hollows] hoick! hoick! hoick! hoo, hoo, by George I'll be one in the chace.

sp.speaker: Allan.
sp.p: So you may if you will, but I'll have a chace of my own; I'll after yon pretty fac'd puſs.

sp.speaker: Robin.
sp.p: An you do, I'll tell Suſan, mark that my lad.

div.head: SCENE IV.
div.stage: Enter Henry in a hunter's dreſs ſinging.

lg.l: What ſtation on earth ſuch true pleaſures can yield
As love in the grove, or the ſtag in the field:
When fatigu'd with the chace in the grove we repoſe,
And Dian her tribute to Cupid beſtows.

sp.p:
Now to ſair Emma, who knows not who I am, but believes me to be a baniſhed man: I have
play'd upon her in diſguiſe, and in a peaſant's garb, made more advancements in her good eſteem than the gayeſt knight, or fopling of the court, with all the glaring outſide of ſucceſs, who woo but with their cloaths.
But yonder come ſome gentlemen of the hunt, proclaiming by their ſhouts the pleaſures of a well-ſpent day.
Joy to ye, gentlemen, the ſport has been ſucceſsful.

sp.speaker: 1ſt Huntſman.
sp.p: Thanks to you, Sir.

sp.speaker: 2d Huntſman.
sp.p: I think I never ſaw ſo fine a chace; there has been much danger too.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: The more the danger greater ſtill the ſport. I ſaw a ruſtic ſcouring yonder cliff, and being eager in purſuit, unluckily he tript, and tumbled headlong down, but fortunately for him he was received by the friendly ſtream below, which broke his fall, that otherwiſe muſt have broke his neck.

sp.speaker: Both Huntſmen.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha! poor fellow.

sp.speaker: 1ſt Huntſman.
sp.p: If he had happened to have been in love, ſuch a tumble might have cured him.—But come, my appetite is keen, I linger for refreſhment, let's towards home.

sp.speaker: 2d Huntſman.
sp.p: Your company will be a pleaſure to us, Sir, if you are diſpoſed this way.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: Sir, my diſpoſition is to comply with every kind entreaty; the day is on the decline, and I am far from home; my horſe is at a cottage near at hand—this is my way, and ſhould have been right glad if chance had made it your's.

sp.speaker: 1ſt Huntſman.
sp.p: Then take good care you meet not with a witch.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: A witch!

sp.speaker: 2d Huntſman.
sp.p: Aye, but a lovely one, with many charms, and witches deal in charms you know.

lg.head: SONG.
lg.l: Take care, good Sir, how you paſs,
There's danger, I aſſure you,
Shou'd you meet the pretty laſs
Perhaps ſhe may allure you.
There is witchcraft in each eye,
No mortal can reſiſt 'em;
Pouting lips of coral die,
Oh! how I could have kiſt 'em.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: I do not underſtand you; enchantment and witchcraft! what may you mean?

sp.speaker: 1ſt Huntſman.
sp.p: Why, Sir, I'll tell you: as we came along the ſkirts of this wood, a lovely damſel, wrapt in thought, was walking to and fro beneath the ſhade; now and then ſhe'd preſs her hand againſt her breaſt; then, with eyes full of lovelineſs and tears, ſhe'd look around, ſigh as if her gentle heart would break, and of a ſudden, cry, Oh, wretched me!

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: Of what appearance, pray?

sp.speaker: 2d Huntſman.
sp.p: She wore the habit of a ſhepherdeſs. We entreated the cauſe of her diſtreſs; but ſhe rebuked us for our pains with ſuch a modeſt grace that we retired.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: Poor girl! a love affair perhaps?

sp.speaker: 1ſt Huntſman.
sp.p: I fancy ſo.

sp.speaker: 2d Huntſman.
sp.p: I wiſh I had been the happy object: I'd have given my fortune for her love.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: Then you might have had it, I dare ſay.

sp.speaker: 1ſt Huntſman.
sp.p: I imagine if we had perſevered, a little patience might have brought her to our purpoſe.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p:
Not if ſhe be really in love; reaſon
will argue ineffectually, when love is rooted in the heart.

lg.head: SONG.
lg.l: Reaſon to love is urg'd in vain,
No force can break his ſilken chain,
He reigns without controul:
Unſeen the God directs his dart,
But ſoon we feel th' envenom'd ſmart
Lie rankling in the ſoul.

sp.speaker: 2d Huntſman.
sp.p: Then we'll think no more of her: ſo good day to you, Sir; I'll go and make love to a ſirloin and a bowl of punch, and I warrant I make 'em ſubmit.
sp.stage: [Exeunt Huntſmen ſinging one way, and Henry the other.

sp.speaker: Emma.
sp.p: I ſeek, alas, in vain: Oh, my Henry, where art thou hid? perhaps he's happy with my rival now: ſure there's no pain like love: What ſhall I do? I've loſt my way, fatigu'd and faint in a doubtful ſearch: hold, if I my miſtake not, there's a village in my view; I'll even thence and ſeek refreſhment there.

div.head: SCENE VII.

sp.speaker: Allan.
sp.p: You ſee I've overte'en you, ſweetheart; I told you I would follow you.

sp.speaker: Emma.
sp.p: Was ever maid ſo wretched! I had no ſooner promiſed myſelf a comfort, but I am interrupted by a fool.

sp.speaker: Allan.
sp.p: What be'ant you well yet?

sp.speaker: Emma.
sp.p: Good clown leave me.

sp.speaker: Allan.
sp.p: Clown, forſooth clown! [aſide] I, I, I, am not a clown, ſweetheart.

sp.speaker: Emma.
sp.p: Then you're as ſimple.

sp.speaker: Allan.
sp.p: If you was a little better acquainted with me you would not ſay ſo.

sp.speaker: Emma.
sp.p: I am ſure of it already. What would you have? Why do you follow me ſo?

sp.speaker: Allan.
sp.p: Why I cannot help it, becauſe I love you.

sp.speaker: Emma.
sp.p: And for that I muſt fall in love with thee too? being the moſt frightful of thy ſex: if that don't rid me of him, I ſhall begin to pity him, leſt he ſhould feel on my account what I for Henry feel. [Aſide.]

sp.speaker: Allan.
sp.p:
Ah, I don't mind that tho'; you
don't think ſo, I'm ſure: you pretty laſſes like a deal of courting.

lg.head: SONG.
lg.l: You frown and look ſhy,
But I know not for why,
'Tis only to try if I love:
Should I go away,
I know you'd cry ſtay,
Ods niggars but I'll never move.
I know very well,
If you love you wont tell,
But ſmother with art your deſire.
You may call me a fool,
And ſeem to be cool,
When your pretty dear heart is on fire.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: As I live 'tis my Emma in diſguiſe: 'Sdeath, but why is this ruſtic with her? Is it for him ſhe came or me? I'll know. She ſhall not ſee me yet, I will firſt turn myſelf to a wizzard; concealed in that I'll ſift the ſecret out.

sp.speaker: Emma.
sp.p:
Pray, good fellow, leave me; if thou doſt love me I'm ſorry for't from my ſoul, ſince my heart is another's, it is not in my power to
love; I would be thy friend in any thing elſe; but let me beg of thee never to mention love to me again.

sp.speaker: Allan.
sp.p: O but I will; I know you can't help loving when you are a little better acquainted with me; for I have often heard my granny ſay that two chumps that had been a good many years together in our houſe, fell in love with one another, and it was a hard matter to part them.

sp.speaker: Emma.
sp.p: That is to ſay, ſhould I be as great a log as thyſelf, I muſt of courſe fall in love with thee, if there were nobody elſe in the world.

sp.speaker: Allan.
sp.p: Hey! how's that? You puzzle me there too; I don't know what to make of that ſaying; I never heard of it before in all my born days; Will you ſay it again? I'll gueſs at it better; (I dad ſhe talks better than Sue; ſhe'll be too much for me if I don't take care). [Aſide.

sp.speaker: Emma.
sp.p:
This looby teazes me to death; would to Heaven I could get rid of him; his obſtinacy makes me begin to fear him; I am perplexed when I think what I have done! I dare not go home, and if I ſtay here I ſhall be
ruined and ſuſpected: O my Henry, thy Emma's loſt, a wanderer forlorn.

lg.head: SONG.
lg.l: O could my voice but reach thine ears;
Didſt thou but ſee theſe falling tears
Thou woulſt not let me here complain
Or drop one ſingle tear in vain.
Some friendly guardian lend me aid,
Direct a poor bewilder'd maid.
Tell me, O tell me, if you can,
Where I ſhall find my baniſh'd man.

sp.speaker: Allan.
sp.p: I dad thou'rt a main good ſinger; if thou ſing'ſt much more in that ſtrain it will bewitch me; Sue cannot ſing half ſo well: ſhe can ſing nothing but,

lg.l: As I trudg'd out one morning to Derry-down dale,
To eat a hot cake, and to drink ſome good ale,
I met with a maiden whoſe cheeks were as red,
As a ſweet damaſk roſe or a ſtrawberry bed.

sp.p: I learnt her to ſing it tho' by the bye; can you ſing it? 'Tis a good merry ſong, if you knew it.

sp.speaker: Emma.
sp.p:
Pray thee go ſing by thyſelf; I am not diſpoſed for mirth juſt now: take thyſelf
away, good fellow, and ſome other time I may liſten to thee.

sp.speaker: Allan.
sp.p: Why that's kind too; but where ſhall I ſee you another time?

sp.speaker: Emma.
sp.p: Why here perhaps, or hereabout.

sp.speaker: Allan.
sp.p: But what will you give me for remembrance?

sp.speaker: Emma.
sp.p: Any thing you ſhall aſk that is in my power.

sp.speaker: Allan.
sp.p: Done with you, done with you; give me a kiſs—'tis a fair bargain.

sp.speaker: Emma.
sp.p: What ſhall I do? I believe I muſt hold him my hand to get rid of him. Why if thou wilt promiſe to go away directly thou ſhalt kiſs my hand.

div.stage: Enter Henry in a conjurer's dreſs, ſeeing Allan kiſs Emma's hand.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: Torture! what do I ſee? Is it poſſible?

sp.speaker: Emma.
sp.p: Heavens! Who is this? [Seeing Henry.

sp.speaker: Allan.
sp.p: The devil I believe—he's ugly enough—don't be afraid—he ſhan't hurt thee.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p:
Ye gentle pair fly not from me; be
happy, I'll retire again rather than diſturb you, for lovers like to be by themſelves.

sp.speaker: Allan.
sp.p: Why that's true enough, old one; you are right there: I warrant you have been in love in your time.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: I have, and feel the pangs of it to this day.

sp.speaker: Allan.
sp.p: Poor ſoul, poor ſoul.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: Fair one I have ſomething to impart to thee in private, and what concerns thee nearly.

sp.speaker: Allan.
sp.p: No, no, don't hear him, he's a wizzard; come away, ſweetheart, come away.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: Clodpole hold thy peace.

sp.speaker: Allan.
sp.p: Don't call me clodpole, an you do, I'll give you a clout.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: Fair maid will you anſwer me one queſtion?

sp.speaker: Emma.
sp.p: Alas! I know not what to ſay.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: Tell me then, do you not ſeek a baniſhed man?

sp.speaker: Emma.
sp.p: Heavens be witneſs, I do indeed!

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: Would intelligence on that head be welcome to thee?

sp.speaker: Emma.
sp.p: My heart, my eyes, my ears are open to receive it; ſpeak—ſpeak of him forever.

sp.speaker: Allan.
sp.p: Plague on's ugly face I ſay; I don't like 'im, he's bewitched the pretty creature already.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: As what I'm going to ſay requires ſecrecy, I muſt beg this ſwain to retire a while 'till I have related my ſtory; but if your affections are ſo ſtrongly rooted that you cannot bear a moment's ſeparation, I will withdraw and let it die with me.

sp.speaker: Emma.
sp.p: No, rather talk forever, if Henry be thy theme; if thy ſtory be retarded by this fellow's preſence, would to Heaven I had a giant's ſtrength that I might ſpurn him from my ſight; for like an hateful inſect has he teazed me, 'till I ſickened with impatience and diſguſt.

sp.speaker: Robin within.
sp.p: Hola! Sue! Sue! here, my laſs, here they are.

sp.speaker: Emma.
sp.p: More interruptions! perplexing fates!

sp.speaker: Allan.
sp.p: Hey dey! what Sue? [ſpeaks in a fright] O the devil take this wizzard I ſay; this is ſome of his doing I ſuppoſe: Sue would never have come I'm ſure if he had not conjured her: ſhe never could have found me if the devil had not had a hand in it. [Aſide.]

sp.speaker: Robin.
sp.p: So maſter Allan we have found you, in the devil's company too I believe, at laſt. [ſeeing Henry] What do you call him when he's ready?

sp.speaker: Allan.
sp.p: A wizzard of the woods if you like: I believe in my heart he has bewitched this ſweet creature here.

sp.speaker: Robin.
sp.p: And here comes one that you have bewitched I'm afraid.

div.stage: Enter Sue in a paſſion and in tears.

lg.head: SONG.
lg.l: Alas, alas, I ſee 'tis true;
O Allan, you've deceiv'd your Sue,
With your promiſes ſo civil;
O you ſly bewitching devil!
I could tear myſelf to pieces;
My fear and jealouſy encreaſes:
I'll go and hang me on yon willow,
And, when dead, I'll haunt thy pillow.
Thou ne'er ſhalt find a maid ſo true,
As poor deceiv'd diſtracted Sue.

sp.speaker: Allan.
sp.p: Nay, but Sue, now Sue; don't go to frighten one: who the devil put all this in thy head? Don't be jealous girl, don't be jealous.

sp.speaker: Sue.
sp.p: Don't you give me cauſe then, you falſe-hearted deceitful cruel creature? Jealous! how would you like to have been ſerv'd ſo? Did not you threaten to hang yourſelf laſt night if I ever let Ralph kiſs me again? And now you have been raking the duce knows where, after the devil knows who all day long.

sp.speaker: Robin.
sp.p: Well ſaid Sue; give it him, ha, ha, ha, I dad this is the beſt ſport I have ſeen ſome time.

sp.speaker: Allan.
sp.p: Nay, you ſhould not blame me for being a little waggiſh: Did not you ſay you lov'd a rake to your heart? Why I have done no harm.

sp.speaker: Sue.
sp.p: I am ſure you can't have been doing any good when you have been in the woods all day with ſuch a wanton looking huſſey as that is; I wiſh ſhe was in the houſe of correction, a ſtraggling rambling minx.

sp.speaker: Emma.
sp.p: Alas, I am undone!

sp.speaker: Sue.
sp.p: There, there, ſhe ſays ſhe is undone.

sp.speaker: Allan.
sp.p: But not by me! I have not done it.

sp.speaker: Emma.
sp.p: Creature, ceaſe thy infamy, and take thy looby and thyſelf away.

lg.head: SONG.
lg.l: Ye reptiles, earth-worms, fly this place,
Ye refuſe of the human race,
I will no more your ſcandal bare,
Whilſt thus I'm rack'd 'tween hope and fear;
For O I've loſt the deareſt ſwain
That ever trod the verdant plain:
Ye cruel miniſters of woe,
Why do you rack a maiden ſo?

sp.speaker: Sue.
sp.p: There, do but hear her now; ſhe is crying becauſe ſhe thinks ſhe has loſt you. O the hypocrite! 'twill break my heart; I'll never believe but there has been ſomething between you.

sp.speaker: Robin.
sp.p: Well done Sue.

sp.speaker: Allan.
sp.p: Why, you're miſtaken now; there has been nothing but—but—but—

sp.speaker: Sue.
sp.p: But what? Oh mercy upon me! he is afraid to ſay what.

sp.speaker: Allan.
sp.p: Nothing but words.

sp.speaker: Robin.
sp.p:
Oh if there has been nothing between
them but words, they muſt have been very cloſe together indeed, Sue.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: I can hear no more of this; if you don't all inſtantly leave this place, I will rivet you in a tree, or turn you all to ſtone; I'll cramp your limbs with my magic power 'till ye ſhall beg to die.

sp.speaker: Robin.
sp.p: O, the devil take all the wizzards I ſay.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: What? ſay you ſo again, and I'll encircle you with toads and adders—away—begone.

sp.speaker: Robin.
sp.p: Lud have mercy upon us. Pray don't, and I'll away directly. Well done Sue [Sue runs off in a fright]. Come, come Allan, you don't know who you have got in company with.

sp.speaker: Allan.
sp.p: If I don't acquaint his worſhip I'll be hang'd, mind that Mr. Conjurer.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: Now, maiden fair, to my ſtory.

sp.speaker: Emma.
sp.p: I'm all attention.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p:
Alas, to be further plunged into affliction; I fear you are in love: if ſo, I am ſorry for you indeed; and if Henry be the object of your affections, I'd have you ceaſe to love, and fix on ſome one more deſerving. He
is a reveller, an outlaw, and in my opinion will come to ſome unſeemly end.

sp.speaker: Emma.
sp.p: Ah me, when ſhall I meet a comfort more!

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: Never in him I fear: Henry is betrothed to many, but is falſe to all: he makes it his ſtudy to deceive your ſex, and boaſts of it when done.

sp.speaker: Emma.
sp.p: Still muſt I love him. O my heart! alas, 'tis breaking, Henry! Oh my Henry! [She faints.]

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: O matchleſs girl! I have kill'd thee I'm afraid! Curſe on my cruelty! I have made too ſevere a trial of her taintleſs love.—Hold, ſhe revives; thanks to the fates, who are kinder to me than I deſerve.—What ſhall I do? If I diſcover myſelf to her now, the ſudden tranſition of grief to joy may kill her quite. Sweet maid take comfort.

sp.speaker: Emma.
sp.p: Where is comfort to be found if my Henry be falſe?

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p:
I am his friend, and will be your's. I never failed in my perſuaſions whenever I wanted to work him to my purpoſe; and indeed I have given him a worſe name than he deſerves. Why he is ſo great a changeling he
believes all women to be more fickle than himſelf; this I've often heard him ſay; adding too, that if he could once find out a maid conſtant and ſincere in her affections to a proof, he would take her to his heart forever: I'll to him, and convince him of your ſincere regard and matchleſs love.

sp.speaker: Emma.
sp.p: O take me with thee too.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: That would marr all; leave it to me, I will hazard my life in the ſucceſs.

lg.l: Take comfort, thou deſerving maid,
Thy matchleſs truth ſhall be repaid;
Thy Henry, ſwift as thought, ſhall fly,
And cheer thy love-afflicted eye.
O may thy friendly ſpeech ſucceed,
Then wilt thou make me bleſt indeed;
And if I e'er ungrateful prove,
May heaven rob me of my love.

div.stage: Enter Juſtice Sightleſs, Allan, Robin, Sue, Conſtables, Huſbandmen, &c.

sp.speaker: Juſtice.
sp.p: Lay hold of him, and I'll take care of her: I'll ſee whether your enchantment or my authority be ſtrongeſt.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: Good Sir, what do you mean?

sp.speaker: Juſtice.
sp.p: O, I'll tell you preſently: you'll turn people into ſtone, and wedge them up in trees will you? If you be a wizzard, as I'm afraid you are, I'll ſee what I can turn you into.

sp.speaker: Robin.
sp.p: Wounds, how grim he looks!

lg.l: Althof, meaſter wizzard,
You growl in your gizzard,
It will not one farthing avail;
His worſhip has caught you,
Now ſoon ſhall be taught you
What conjurers do in a jail.
You made Allan untrue,
To roſy cheek'd Sue,
And fright the poor girl into fits:
What you ſaid, I declare,
Made me wonder and ſtare,
And ſcar'd me quite out of my wits.
Would his worſhip permit,
I do think it more fit,
To ſet the old rogue in a blaze:
Tho' hard loaded with chains,
He may 'ſcape all our pains,
Since the devil will help him he ſays.
Then let's lead him along
To a ſtake that is ſtrong,
And give him a taſte of the fire:
There is nothing can thrive
While the wizzard's alive,
Then ſend him at once to his ſire.

div.trailer: The End of the Firſt Act.

div.head: ACT II.
SCENE I.
div.stage: Enter Sightleſs in his cap and night-gown.

lg.l: I Crept out of bed, and I ſlipt on my clothes,
And I left my old wife in a hearty good doze:
I turn'd the key ſoftly, and open'd the door,
Whilſt ſhe moſt conveniently ſet up a ſnore.
At other times, faith, I have thought it uncivil,
And wiſh'd her oft ſnoring away at the devil:
May ſhe ſnore, may ſhe ſnort; may ſhe ſnort, may ſhe ſnore:
May ſhe take ſuch a nap that ſhe never wake more.

sp.speaker: Sightleſs.
sp.p:
I'm bewitch'd with this wench to be ſure; for of all the red and white, the ſoft and ſmooth, I never ſaw her equal; ſhe ran in my
head ſo much all night, that I did nothing but dream of her: I muſt feel how her pulſe beat: I would not ſend her to priſon for fear ſomebody elſe might make too free with her, troth. Odds me, here ſhe comes! I intended to have had the pleaſure of waking her myſelf, but ſhe has prevented me.

sp.speaker: Sight.
sp.p: So, ſweetheart, you're up: what, did not you ſleep well?

sp.speaker: Emma.
sp.p: I have not ſlept at all.

sp.speaker: Sight.
sp.p: Not ſlept?

sp.speaker: Emma.
sp.p: Scarce a wink.

sp.speaker: Sight.
sp.p: Then I'm afraid you have been contriving how to make your eſcape.

sp.speaker: Emma.
sp.p: That I never can, for I am bound in chains forever.

sp.speaker: Sight.
sp.p: Bound in chains? How how do you mean, laſs, bound in chains? Why you talk in your ſleep to be ſure: Where the deuce be your chains? I ſee nothing of 'em.

sp.speaker: Emma.
sp.p: I feel them tho', but would not break 'em for the world.

sp.speaker: Sight.
sp.p: Good lack-a-day, ſhe is certainly aſleep yet: E'dad I'll wake her tho'; hallo! hallo!
sp.stage: [Lays hold of her and ſhakes her.

sp.speaker: Emma.
sp.p: Bleſs me, Sir, what is the matter?

sp.speaker: Sight.
sp.p: What's the matter child! You walk in your ſleep!

sp.speaker: Emma.
sp.p: I rather think that you walk in your ſleep, who cannot ſee that I'm awake.

sp.speaker: Sight.
sp.p: I'dad perhaps I do: hey—no, no, I'm not aſleep: come, huſſy, give me a buſs; and that will wake me, were I dead.

div.head: SCENE III.
div.stage: Mrs. Sightleſs ruſhes in upon him.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sightleſs.
sp.p:
Yes, I dare ſay it wou'd: you're aſleep are you! You're aſleep, and you muſt come here to be kiſs'd awake: O you vile
man! This is what you had her in the houſe for! This is your conſcience, is it! You would not ſend her to priſon forſooth, for fear ſhe might prove innocent; and now you have ſneak'd out of bed, like a falſe-hearted monſter as you are, in your ſleep on purpoſe to have this ſanctify'd hypocrite wake you with her kiſſes.

sp.speaker: Sight.
sp.p: No, no, my dear, you have convinced me that we were both awake with a vengeance; I wiſh you were aſleep with all my heart.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sight.
sp.p: Yes, I dare ſay you do.

sp.speaker: Sight.
sp.p: Yes, and the devil take him that wakes you, ſhould you ſleep 'till Doomſday.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sight.
sp.p: O you brute! you ſavage! you ſcandalous good-for-nothing creature you! but this is all your doing, madam Wag-tail, I'll ſoon ſend you a packing!—Huſſy, I've a good mind to tear your eyes out.

sp.speaker: Sight.
sp.p: You had better tear your tongue out, you jealous pated fool you! What a clack you keep indeed!

sp.speaker: Emma.
sp.p: Madam hear me.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sight.
sp.p: I won't hear you: don't talk to me: I ſhall go mad I believe.

sp.speaker: Sight.
sp.p: You're mad enough already I think.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sight.
sp.p: And who may I thank for it but you? but I'll be reveng'd.

sp.speaker: Sight.
sp.p: Why, look you wife; you are only making a fire for yourſelf all this time: you'll burn yourſelf up with your own fury: I did aſk the young woman to kiſs me indeed, but 'twas only in joke.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sight.
sp.p: In joke! a pretty joke indeed! If I had not come in as I did, I dare ſay you'd have made a ſerious affair of it by this time! In joke forſooth! A very modeſt joke, I dare ſay!

lg.l: Palm not your wanton tricks on me,
Your baſe deſigns, vile man! I ſee:
No, no, I won't deſpair.
Fierce fury in my breaſt ſhall riſe:
What! bring your minx before my eyes?
This is too much to bear.
My vengeance ſhall you both purſue;
I'll do for her—I'll do for you—
Theſe favours I'll return:
Altho' her tender heart ſhou'd break,
The wizard's fate ſhall ſhe partake,
And both together burn.

sp.speaker: Emma.
sp.p: Madam, you may form what opinion you will of your own, becauſe time and appearances may have given you ſome authority for your ſuſpicions: nothing but ill manners and a guilty mind can warrant your judging ſo illiberally of a ſtranger.

sp.speaker: Sight.
sp.p: Bleſſings on her, ſhe prattles like an angel.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sight.
sp.p: Prithee, wench, don't prate ſo pertly to me: do you know who I am?

sp.speaker: Emma.
sp.p: Yes, madam, I am very ſenſible to whom I'm talking; a ſplenetic—

sp.speaker: Sight.
sp.p: A what! a lunatic! mind what you ſay girl; remember ſhe is my wife, and therefore claims reſpect.

sp.speaker: Emma.
sp.p: I've ſaid nothing but the truth, Sir, and I ſhall always pay a greater regard to that than her ungenerous reflections, or your authority.

sp.speaker: Sight.
sp.p: Hey! what do you ſay? Do you mean to affront me for my indulgence? I muſt ſeem to quarrel with her for the ſake of peace and quietneſs, or I ſhall have a dog's life on't elſe. [Aſide.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sight.
sp.p:
Aye, aye, I'm glad on't; I'm glad you begin to find her out. Innocent! yes
ſhe's very innocent, to be ſure, you may ſee that; but as impudent as you pleaſe: ſend her to priſon, I inſiſt on it—an impudent ſtragling huſſy!

sp.speaker: Sight.
sp.p: I believe I muſt indeed: ſhe makes but a bad uſe of my civility: come, come, you ſhall go to priſon huſſy; I'll ſee if I can't make room for you there.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sight.
sp.p: No, no, I'll ſave you that trouble; I'll take care to make room for her myſelf, I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Emma.
sp.p: Alas! my reſolution totters—arm me with fortitude, ye gracious powers, nor leave me to deſpair.

lg.l: Come Hope, thou blooming maid, appear,
Shield, O ſhield me from diſpair.
Teach me, ye gods, to undergo
The love-tormenting pangs of woe.
And if I die, O let me prove
A faithful monument of love:
Then, then, my Henry, ſhalt thou ſee,
Thy Emma kept her words with thee.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sight.
sp.p: Come, come, away with you; I've ſomething elſe to do than to hear your whining forſooth.

sp.speaker: Sight.
sp.p: Aye, aye, to priſon with her. I have a key for that lock too; I'll have a peep at her there. [aſide.]

sp.speaker: Sue.
sp.p: No, no, I won't ſpeak to thee; I won't look at thee; I won't think of thee, I won't, I won't, ſo I won't.

sp.speaker: Allan.
sp.p: Nay, plague on't Sue, don't be hard hearted: you know I love you, you know I do.

sp.speaker: Sue.
sp.p: I don't know it, nor I won't know it, you ſhan't love me.

sp.speaker: Robin.
sp.p: Well ſaid Sue, don't give out, remember the girl in the grove.

sp.speaker: Allan.
sp.p: Hold thy tongue Robin, and don't be a fool.

sp.speaker: Robin.
sp.p: A fool! not I indeed, I'm not in love, I'm wiſe enough for that.

lg.l: The fair or the hrown,
A ſmile or a frown,
All ever are equal to me:
I laugh and I ſmile,
Love cannot beguile
A heart that is jovial and free.
Let fond loving ſwains,
Keep ſigning their pains;
No wench ſhall my freedom annoy,
And yet I am ſure
For love there's a cure,
Since time will that paſſion deſtroy.

sp.speaker: Sue.
sp.p: [to Allen] Don't keep teazing me ſo; don't think I can forget it, don't.

sp.speaker: Allan.
sp.p: Ay, but you can forgive it Sue: you had always a pure tender heart of your own.

sp.speaker: Sue.
sp.p: No, the duce take me if I do.

sp.speaker: Robin.
sp.p: No, don't Sue, make him repent it all the days of his life.

sp.speaker: Allan.
sp.p: If thee don't hold thy tongue I'll make thee repent it.

sp.speaker: Robin.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, wilt?

sp.speaker: Allan.
sp.p: Yes I will.

sp.speaker: Robin.
sp.p: No, no, thee can't do that, except thee cou'd make me in love with every wench that I meet, like thyſelf, to yelp after this, and to whine after t'other, and—odds niggars don't mind him Sue, don't mind him, he's in love with a thouſand.

sp.speaker: Sue.
sp.p: O what a fool have I been!

sp.speaker: Robin.
sp.p: A fool indeed.

sp.speaker: Allan.
sp.p: It's as falſe as old nick.

lg.l: Your words I deny,
Don't give me the lie:
I never lov'd any but Sue.
You fain now wou'd try,
To part Sue and I,
But, Robin, your nonſence won't do.
You may giggle and grin,
I care not a pin,
If Sue will believe that I love:
Altho' you impeach
You can't make a breach,
Since truth will each falſhood remove.

sp.speaker: Robin
sp.p: Pſhaw, pſhaw, no more of this nonſenſe: Sue what do you think of me, hey? Come give me a buſs and tell me.

sp.speaker: Sue.
sp.p: Prithee, Robin, don't play the fool with me.

sp.speaker: Robin.
sp.p: I play the fool! not I indeed! prithee don't lay your bargains on me; it is you that have play'd the fool I'm afraid, I'm ſure I'd no hand in't; if you have made a ſlip I can't help it.

sp.speaker: Allan.
sp.p: You was always a fool.

sp.speaker: Robin.
sp.p: A fool! ha, ha, ha, give me thy hand o'that—how is't brother?—if I be a fool, I'm ſure I muſt be ſome relation of your's.

sp.speaker: Robin.
sp.p: Hey! to paſs, what is the matter now?

sp.speaker: Sue.
sp.p: To ſay I had made a ſlip!

lg.head: SONG.
lg.l: I wiſh I never had ſeen a man,
They're treach'rous as the devil,
And like the devil too, they can
Be very, very civil.
O dear! O dear! what ſhall I do?
I'm ſure my heart will burſt:
You falſe deceitful wretches you,
Of monſiers you're the worſt.

sp.stage: [Exit Sue, Allan going after her, Robin lays hold of him and prevents him.

sp.speaker: Robin.
sp.p: Why, you would not be ſuch a fool, would you?

sp.speaker: Allan.
sp.p: Yes but I wou'd.

sp.speaker: Robin.
sp.p: No, no, let her come to herſelf; if ſhe won't bear a joke now and then, I wou'd not give a ruſh for her.

sp.speaker: Allan.
sp.p: 'Swounds, but I ſhall have ne'er a ſweetheart at this rate.

sp.speaker: Robin.
sp.p: Pſhaw, pſhaw, what a ſimpleton you are indeed! you want ſadly to hurry your neck into the nooſe methinks: come, come, you and I will have a little ſport firſt.

lg.head: SONG.
lg.l: For ſhou'd you Sue wed,
And lead her to bed,
No mortal ſo happy as you:
The honey-moon paſt,
You'll find at the laſt
The wonder will ceaſe to be new.
Come, come, then away,
'Tis fooliſh to ſtay,
With me trudge along to the wake;
There's plenty you'll find,
To cheer up your mind,
And ſhe you like beſt you may take.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: 'Tis high time now to make enquiry after my love; I've had a reſtleſs night on't; this is a trial I never dreamt of; if ſhe bears this with fortitude, ſhe will be indeed the wonder of her ſex, and worthy the richeſt diadem on earth: that I love her, my heart and ſoul can witneſs: if after this ſhe talks of love and Henry, I ſhall be convinced that women can be conſtant, and every doubt muſt fade; but who comes here? a ſtranger; and a priſoner I ſuppoſe; perhaps he can inform me where my Emma is diſpoſed.

sp.speaker: Edwin.
sp.p: Your pardon, Sir, I've interceded with the jailor for admittance, and ſhou'd be glad of your conſent to exchange a word or two: report has made me curious, but if it has made me too impertinent, I will retire, and not offend you.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: Sir, you do me honour; I am glad to ſee you: 'ſdeath, who can this be? his face is moſt familiar to me [aſide]: Sir, you are welcome.

sp.speaker: Edwin.
sp.p: I thank you Sir.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: Ah, me!

sp.speaker: Edwin.
sp.p: You ſeem diſturbed Sir.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: A thought came acroſs the ſunſhine of my hopes; but now—but now 'tis fair again.

sp.speaker: Edwin.
sp.p: There is ſomething more than common about this man, and a ſenſible affability that pleaſes me much. [Aſide.]

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: You ſeem to muſe Sir; I hope you've no deſign?

sp.speaker: Edwin.
sp.p: As your ſuſpicions are but natural, they do not much ſurpriſe me; but on my faith I've no deſign: I am a priſoner as yourſelf, and ſhould have been glad, had it been your inclination too, to have paſs'd an heavy hour now and then together, and been friends, that is all.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: You ſpeak, Sir, like a gentleman, and are moſt welcome I aſſure you; and as you have offered me your friendſhip, you ſhall find me grateful and ſincere: I'm grieved to find a man with ſuch a heart, in ſuch a ſituation; but come, let us be chearful.

lg.head: SONG.
lg.l: Tho' care with heavy hands oppreſs,
And fortune leaves us to diſtreſs,
Yet ſhou'd the Gods once condeſcend,
To bleſs me with a ſingle friend,
I wou'd not call the fates unkind,
Tho' thus impriſon'd and confin'd,
Friendſhip ſhou'd drive my cares away,
And make me hope a better day.

sp.speaker: Edwin.
sp.p: I have not had ſo agreeable an interview theſe twelvemonths.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: Theſe twelvemonths! I hope you've not been here ſo long.

sp.speaker: Edwin.
sp.p: Much longer Sir.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: I'm ſorry for it; your crime ſurely muſt be great indeed, to incur ſo long a puniſhment.

sp.speaker: Edwin.
sp.p: I think I may venture to ſay it is more an accident than a crime.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: Priſons were not made for the unfortunate, but the wicked and abandon'd: may I preſume to enquire the cauſe? perhaps I may have it in my power to be your friend.

sp.speaker: Edwin.
sp.p: Alas, I am afraid not in ſuch a caſe: my father's death was all the cauſe.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: Impriſon'd for your father's death! Shall I intreat your name? perhaps I am too bold.

sp.speaker: Edwin.
sp.p: My name, Sir, is Edwin: I was born at Philodale.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: At Philodale! as I live my old ſchoolfellow, and my ſiſter's lover; how fortunate! [aſide] but I cannot underſtand, Sir, how your father's death could be the cauſe of your impriſonment.

sp.speaker: Edwin.
sp.p:
When he died he left a perſon in this neighbourhood his executor (Sightleſs) who
you muſt have ſeen; but, tho' he bears the name of Juſtice, he is, I am afraid, as great a ſtranger to her rules, as he is to pity. He ever pretended that my father died involved; and, as I could not contradict it, was forc'd to think ſo too: this was a ſad ſhock, tho' the leaſt of my affliction; for I was betroth'd to the lovlieſt maid, whoſe fortune was almoſt equal to her beauty; but, alas, becoming deſtitute and poor, cou'd never think of ſeeing her again, and wrote her word I meant to paſs the ſeas, never to return.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: O moſt diſtreſſing tale! but pray go on.

sp.speaker: Edwin.
sp.p:
Before my father died, having an occaſion for a certain ſum, previous to his knowledge, which I had ſcarcely hinted to his worſhip, but he begged he might oblige me; I thought it kindneſs, and gladly embraced the opportunity; I gave my note with promiſe of a double intereſt; but ere the beſt of fathers had cloſed his eyes, and my time for the payment of the debt unfortunately expir'd, he hurry'd me to priſon, where I have been a ſad and melancholy being ever ſince: I wou'd have wrote to certain friends, but he has cruelly deprived me
of that advantage by giving the jailor the ſtricteſt charge never to place a pen and ink within my reach, or let one letter paſs the door, which action has often made me think he's play'd me foul.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: No doubt Sir: O the villain! come my worthy friend, do not diſpair: I have a charm about me that ſhall extricate us both: if you dare venture to aſſiſt, I'll prove your friend: I have a ſtratagem on foot, by which you'll find I ll make a fair example of his worſhip, and you ſhall be reveng'd; and if they refuſe us liberty, here is a key that will unlock the ſtrongeſt bolt.

sp.speaker: Edwin.
sp.p: Then you may command me, and depend on my integrity; I ſhall not dread the conſequence or danger, ſince if we fail they cannot make us greater priſoners than we are; if they take my life 'twill be a charity.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: If I don't preſerve both life and liberty, I'll reſign my own; I want to be your friend.

sp.speaker: Edwin.
sp.p: And I want liberty; propoſe your plan, I long to be in action.

lg.head: SONG.
lg.l: Who would not die
For liberty?
What wretch would bear to live a ſlave,
And fear the cord, the rack, or grave?
I will not bear,
Nor guiltleſs wear
The cruel chains of infamy;
No, no, I'd ſooner die.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: Then to the point: you have heard no doubt on what ſuſpicion I was committed; the ſuperſtition of the ruſticks, has poſſeſt 'em meerly from my appearance, that I deal in witchcraft.

sp.speaker: Edwin.
sp.p: 'Twas that report that firſt excited me to viſit you.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: When I found they firſt ſuſpected it, I endeavoured to make 'em believe that I really did, by threat'ning them in the moſt romantic phraſes.—But I may depend on your integrity you ſay.

sp.speaker: Edwin.
sp.p: You may, Sir, on the forfeit of my life.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: Then, that you may not be deceived, I am not what I ſeem.

sp.speaker: Edwin.
sp.p: Indeed I did ſuſpect it.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: No more on that head at preſent; but why I bear this character you ſhall know hereafter; be ſatisfied, you ſhall not remain a priſoner here another day; were I to declare myſelf they wou'd gladly give me liberty; yet as I have a reaſon for this ſtrange project, I will go thro' it.

sp.speaker: Edwin.
sp.p: You tranſport me with pleaſure and aſtoniſhment.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: What moſt concerns me is, there was a fair one in my company, whom they have impriſon'd too, without the ſmalleſt circumſtance of guilt, only that ſhe was with me.

sp.speaker: Edwin.
sp.p: There was the moſt lovely maid I ever ſaw brought this morning to the priſon.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: This morning!

sp.speaker: Edwin.
sp.p: Scarce an hour ſince.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: That's ſtrange! has ſhe not been here all night?

sp.speaker: Edwin.
sp.p: I can aſſure you, no: Sightleſs and his wife brought her this morning; and when his worſhip left the priſon, he gave the ſtricteſt orders to the jailor, that none ſhou'd ſee her but himſelf, which made me pity her indeed.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p:
You amaze me! 'Sdeath, but this
diſturbs me: could not one ſpeak with the jailor?

sp.speaker: Edwin.
sp.p: Moſt certainly: I'll call him hither if you pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: Sir, you'll much oblige me if you wou'd.
sp.stage: [Edwin goes off the ſtage and calls the jailor, and re-enters immediately.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: Don't you think he might be prevailed upon to let us ſee her?

sp.speaker: Edwin.
sp.p: I doubt it much: ſuch men as him are generally ſtrangers to humanity, and ſeldom will be moved to a good action by any thing but a bribe.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: That he ſhall have with all my heart.

sp.speaker: Edwin.
sp.p: Here he comes.

sp.speaker: Jailor.
sp.p:
'Swounds, maſter Edwin, you call with as much authority as his worſhip: What the plague is the matter with you? I thought
you had been hanging yourſelf, and was calling me to cut you down.

sp.speaker: Edwin.
sp.p: That is very probable to be ſure.

sp.speaker: Jailor.
sp.p: Why I wou'd have done it for you to be ſure for my own ſake.

sp.speaker: Edwin.
sp.p: How for your own ſake? what intereſt cou'd you have in that?

sp.speaker: Jailor.
sp.p: What! why your carcaſe and your cloaths: the one I ſhou'd have got a trifle for from the ſurgeons, and the others I wou'd have ſold to the rag-ſhop.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: What a ſavage! Faith, my friend, you ſeem to have a good notion.

sp.speaker: Jailor.
sp.p: Aye, han't I maſter?

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: Nobody a better—Methinks you and I ſhall agree very well.

sp.speaker: Jailor.
sp.p: I don't know that tho'.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: I dare ſay we ſhall: could you let me change a word or two with the young woman you had brought into priſon this morning?

sp.speaker: Jailor.
sp.p: No.—You ſpeak with her hey? What ſhould ſuch an old codger as you want with a young woman? no, no, it won't do; it won't do.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: Will this do? [ſhews him money.]

sp.speaker: Jailor.
sp.p:
Hey? why as you ſay—I don't know
but it may; they are pretty looking fellows enough ſeemingly.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: Are they not? I thought you and I ſhou'd agree; I'm an excellent phyſician you ſee; I know the ſtrength of your conſtitution better than yourſelf you find.

sp.speaker: Jailor.
sp.p: Why aye, you carry a pleaſant kind of phyſic about you; few make a wry face at it, I fancy.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: Don't I? Well, what do you ſay; ſhall we agree?

sp.speaker: Jailor.
sp.p: I don't know what to ſay to it; i'faith I'm almoſt afraid.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: Pſhaw man, what ſhou'd you fear?

lg.head: SONG.
lg.l: Pray who can ſay you are to blame,
Since all your betters do the ſame?
My lord makes harveſt of his place:
Then prithee where's the great diſgrace?
The crime is ſure not worſe in you,
Shou'd you purſue the maxim too:
For greater knaves at any hour,
Will for a bribe reſtrain their power.

sp.speaker: Jailor.
sp.p: Faith, dad, I like your notion; you ſeem to be a good hearty cock; give me your hand: you'll not blow me I hope? you underſtand me.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: No, upon my honour.

sp.speaker: Jailor.
sp.p: Why then 'tis agreed.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: Then take your reward, and ſhew us the way: come my worthy friend, you muſt bear me company.

sp.speaker: Jailor.
sp.p: You don't take him with you I hope. [meaning Edwin.]

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: Yes, by all means.

sp.speaker: Jailor.
sp.p: Nay with all my heart; tho' by the bye, take care his worſhip don't pop in upon you; I expect him here anon, he ſeems to have caſt a longing eye upon her himſelf.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: That will be lucky again, I ſhall be there to protect her: [aſide] O never fear us, we'll take care of ourſelves.
[Without.] Jailor! jailor!

sp.speaker: Jailor.
sp.p: Coming, coming: here take the key; ſhe is in the beſt room: you know the way maſter Edwin; and ſo good luck to you.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: We thank you.

sp.speaker: Jailor.
sp.p:
Blame me but this is a good doſe;
'Egad I ſhould like to take ſuch phyſic every day.

div.head: SCENE VII.
div.stage: Changes to another part of the priſon, and diſcovers Emma.

sp.speaker: Emma.
sp.p: Surely the fates do mean to counteract all my hopes: how perplexing! I was enraptured with the higheſt expectation of ſeeing my Henry ere this, and now he is loſt forever: wou'd I cou'd ſee the honeſt ſtranger once again; perhaps he might inform me where to ſend to him; for did he but know the perilous ſituation I am in, he would ſurely think of ſome way to releaſe me. Alas! ſhould the tidings reach my father's ears, I am undone.

lg.head: SONG.
lg.l: Come, come, my Henry to my aid,
Releaſe thy poor diſtracted maid:
For thee theſe trials do I bear,
But O! how cruel and ſevere.

div.head: SCENE VIII.
div.stage: Henry and Edwin enter in converſation.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: You underſtand me?

sp.speaker: Edwin.
sp.p: Perfectly—behold the fair one.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: O my delight! but thou ſhalt grieve no more: I am convinced.

sp.speaker: Emma.
sp.p: [ſeeing them] Bleſs me! the ſtranger's here: ſurely he o'erheard my prayers.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: Pardon me, thou lovely fair one, for intruding on you thus, for I am more concerned for your misfortune than my own: I could not reſt 'till I had ſeen you once again.

sp.speaker: Emma.
sp.p: Nay you are welcome, for you talk'd of Henry.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: As we broke off ſo abruptly in our converſation relating to that youth, I have taken this opportunity, with your permiſſion, to renew it.

sp.speaker: Emma.
sp.p: O you are kind indeed!—Is this a friend of Henry's too?

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: He is.

sp.speaker: Emma.
sp.p: Then he is moſt welcome. [Edwin bows.]

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: And is it poſſible amidſt your preſent perils and calamity, you can think ſo much of Henry.

sp.speaker: Emma.
sp.p: I think of nothing elſe.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: Then ſhall he know how much thy truth outrates his higheſt expectations; for tho' I ſpoke unkindly of his worth, I but diſſembled, he loves with equal warmth, and ſeldom ſpeaks but you he makes his theme: he will be tranſported with your virtue, and ſhall know it.

sp.speaker: Emma.
sp.p: Know it! alas, which way?

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: I have a ſtratagem on foot for your eſcape, if you will aſſiſt me in it, I will inſtantly convey you to your baniſhed man.

sp.speaker: Emma.
sp.p: I'll riſk my life on ſuch a promiſe.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: His worſhip will be here to viſit you anon: leave this gentleman and me to manage him, and doubt not of ſucceſs.

sp.speaker: Emma.
sp.p: May heaven proſper your endeavours.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: And hark, he comes! we'll retire from his ſight a while 'till we ſeize our opportunity.

sp.speaker: Emma.
sp.p: Alas! I tremble at the taſk.

div.head: SCENE IX.

sp.speaker: Sight.
sp.p: Well, my little rogue, how do you find yourſelf by this time?

sp.speaker: Emma.
sp.p: Not very well you may ſuppoſe, Sir, in my preſent ſituation.

sp.speaker: Sight.
sp.p: I fear not; I fear not indeed: but you ſhou'd not have been here if I cou'd have help'd it: my wife, you ſee is a terrible woman; ſhe will be obey'd.

sp.speaker: Emma.
sp.p: And your compliance, Sir, was a proof of your humility and juſtice.

sp.speaker: Sight.
sp.p: Well ſaid, ſweetee, well ſaid; and ſo it was: I wiſh ſhe was dead tho' by the bye; I'd make thee the happier for it: nay, I'll make thee happy now, if thou'lt love me.

sp.speaker: Emma.
sp.p: That I never can.

sp.speaker: Sight.
sp.p: Ah, but you muſt, and you ſhall; 'ſdeath, if you don't I'll make you.

sp.speaker: Emma.
sp.p: Inded, Sir, I never can.

sp.speaker: Sight.
sp.p:
But you muſt, and you ſhall: I have it in my power, and I'll make thee huſſy; or I'll—come, come, I won't be angry; give me
a bufs, and I'll forgive thee. [He endeavours to kiſs her.]

div.stage: Henry and Edwin come behind him, tye a handkerchief over his eyes, and drag him off the ſtage.

sp.speaker: Emma.
sp.p: Heavens! how will this end! I dread the conſequence!

div.stage: Re-enter Henry and Edwin, Henry in the Juſtice's cloaths.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: Now, now, my fair one, if you'll take your liberty you ſhall have it; in this diſguiſe I can command your diſcharge.

sp.speaker: Emma.
sp.p: I'll embrace the opportunity, tho' I dread it.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: You, my good and faithful friend, may expect your liberty without delay: I'll return and make example of his worſhip preſently.
sp.stage: [Exit Henry and Emma at one door, and Edwin at the other.

div.head: SCENE X.
div.stage: Diſcovers Sightleſs gagg'd, with his hands ty'd behind him, making a noiſe and ſtamping about the ſtage.

sp.speaker: Jailor.
sp.p: Hallow! what the devil is the matter with you old boy? What do you make ſuch a damn'd noiſe for? Did not I tell you to take care of his worſhip? You a conjurer! you a devil! by the bye, now he is blindfolded with his hands tied, I've a good mind to pick his pockets: [aſide] Hey! let me look again—by the lord 'tis his worſhip himſelf: the old one has play'd him a trick:—ſhall I releaſe him or no? [Sightleſs makes a noiſe again] Coming, your worſhip: blame me I muſt releaſe. [Jailor releaſes him.]

sp.speaker: Sight.
sp.p: Oh the damn'd villains! where are they gone? I'll have 'em all hang'd: go bring 'em to me directly.

sp.speaker: Jailor.
sp.p: And pleaſe worſhip, I'm afraid they're off.

sp.speaker: Sight.
sp.p: Off! who's off?

sp.speaker: Jailor.
sp.p: Why, and pleaſe your worſhip, the young woman and Mr. Wizzard, as they call him.

sp.speaker: Sight.
sp.p: What, have you let 'em out?

sp.speaker: Jailor.
sp.p: Blame me if I did not take him for your worſhip, having your worſhip's cloaths on.

sp.speaker: Sight.
sp.p: And you have let them out then?

sp.speaker: Jailor.
sp.p: O yes, your worſhip, they are off indeed!

sp.speaker: Sight.
sp.p: Then if you don't find 'em again you ſhall be hang'd in their ſtead, mark that; but where's the reſt? there were half a dozen of 'em I believe.

sp.speaker: Jailor.
sp.p: I fancy not, and pleaſe your worſhip? I don't believe there was any body in company with him but maſter Edwin and the girl.

sp.speaker: Sight.
sp.p: Edwin! what have you let him out too?

sp.speaker: Jailor.
sp.p: No, your worſhip.

sp.speaker: Sight.
sp.p: That's lucky, that's lucky; he ſhall be hang'd for the reſt, that's ſome comfort: after the others, you dog!

lg.head: SONG.
lg.l: O I'll be reveng'd if I live;
I'll never, no never forgive
Such ſcandalous treatment as this:
Was there e'er ſuch a knave
On this ſide the grave,
To gag up the jaws of Juſtice?

div.trailer: The End of the Second Act.

div.head: SCENE I.
div.stage: Henry and Emma, Henry yet in Sightleſs's cloaths.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: NOW we are ſafe I hope; and as I have promiſed, you ſhall find I'll keep my word: ſee you yond grove? thither go, and as ſure as truth thy Henry ſhall meet thee there: I'll bring him with me ere you well arrive yourſelf.

sp.speaker: Emma.
sp.p: May Heaven bleſs you if you do.—My Henry! ſhall I ſee my baniſhed Henry!

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: And he ſhall meet the too, thou matchleſs fair one, with a heart as warm as ever glow'd with love.

lg.head: SONG.
lg.l: O what a jewel can compare
With the taintleſs heart:
No polliſhed gem is half ſo fair,
As Emma without art.

sp.speaker: Jailor.
sp.p: Aye, aye, this muſt be the way.

sp.speaker: Conſtable.
sp.p: 'Sniggins, if we ſhou'd take 'em it wou'd be rare ſport.

sp.speaker: Jailor.
sp.p: Edad, an we don't it will be bad ſport for me tho', if his worſhip keeps his word.

sp.speaker: Conſtable.
sp.p: Hallow! hallow! who be you when you're ready?

sp.speaker: Jailor.
sp.p: Fetter me but 'tis his worſhip himſelf.

sp.speaker: Conſtable.
sp.p: In troth and ſo it is—well the more the merrier I ſay: God bleſs his worſhip, he's a good natured gentleman, I ſay he is.

sp.speaker: Jailor.
sp.p:
You ſay he is, that's a ſign you know
much of the matter to be ſure; I'm afraid we ſhall ſee little of his good nature 'till we have taken the wizzard and his wench again; but mum—here he comes.

sp.speaker: Sight.
sp.p: Well, my brave lads, what news?

sp.speaker: Jailor.
sp.p: An't pleaſe your worſhip, we met an old fellow juſt now, who told us he ſaw 'em on this road together.

sp.speaker: Sight.
sp.p: Away with you then, away with you; don't ſtand here, but after 'em, or they'll be gone to the devil elſe.

sp.speaker: Conſtable.
sp.p: Your worſhip will follow I hope?

sp.speaker: Sight.
sp.p: Aye, Aye, I'll follow, I'll follow; away with you, away!

lg.head: SONG.
lg.l: By the Lord, if I take 'em once more,
I'll hold 'em as faſt as old nick:
I'll fetter the ſon of a whore,
And make him pay dear for his trick.

sp.speaker: Emma.
sp.p: I'm diſtreſs'd 'tween hope and fear, in doubt if Henry will meet me here or not, and in fear the ſtranger may deceive me.

lg.head: SONG.
DUETTO.
lg.l: Ye gentle miniſters above,
Who rule the heart and guide the eye:
Once more reſtore me to my love,
Or Emma ſoon, too ſoon muſt die.

div.head: SCENE IV.
div.stage: Henry enters in a ſhepherd's dreſs, and lays hold of her hand; Emma ſtarts.

lg.l: O live! O live! thou deareſt maid,
And think of grief and death no more:
No, no, that lilly ne'er ſhall fade,
If I've the power to reſtore.

sp.speaker: Emma.
sp.p: My Henry!

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: Come to his heart, thou trueſt maid! [Embracing.]

sp.speaker: Emma.
sp.p: Bleſt be the hand that pointed me the way: bleſt be the tongue that told me where to come.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: Rather bleſt be ſhe that followed ſuch a guide with ſuch unequall'd faith.

sp.speaker: Emma.
sp.p: Wou'd I cou'd ſee the worthy friend again, that I might think of ſome reward.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: Nay, in truth thou ow'ſt him none; for thou haſt over paid him for his pains.

sp.speaker: Emma.
sp.p: Alas, I've paid him nothing!

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: Indeed, indeed thou haſt! I was thy guide, thy lover, and thy friend!

sp.speaker: Emma.
sp.p: Is it poſſible?

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: It is, and true. [A noiſe at a diſtance.]

sp.speaker: Emma.
sp.p: Ah me! we're ta'en again; for ſee the hateful crew has trac'd us hither.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: So much the better; 'tis juſt as I wou'd wiſh.

sp.speaker: Emma.
sp.p: So much the better?

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p:
Fear not my love, there is no danger; they will be glad to let us go again: I beg, my love, that you will not ſhew one ſign of fear;
for as ſure as you are fair, ſo ſure you'll find no danger: Shall I ſwear?

sp.speaker: Emma.
sp.p: No, no, I have no further doubt; I will not fear: if Henry ſays it, Emma muſt believe.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: Generous maid! that we may not be overcome, I've previouſly ſent for certain friends of mine to meet me there.

sp.speaker: Emma.
sp.p: Friends! alas, what friends?

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: Anon you ſhall know all: the Juſtice is a knave, and I'll expoſe him to the world; but here come his brainleſs inſtruments: I'll divert myſelf with their ſtupidity; and ſeem to make reſiſtance: pray be chearful, and all will be well.

sp.speaker: Jailor.
sp.p:
Oh! by the king of good luck here's ma'am! with a new acquaintance faith; but where's the old one? tho' by the bye I fancy ſhe'll be the moſt welcome prize to his worſhip, and therefore I'll ſecure her firſt: come, miſs,
if you pleaſe, you ſhall go back again to his worſhip with me.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: Go back to his worſhip! for what?

sp.speaker: Jailor.
sp.p: For what! O his worſhip will tell you preſently: he will be here in a trice.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: His worſhip is a knave, and you're a fool: tell him I ſay ſo.

sp.speaker: Jailor.
sp.p: Why, you dog, if you ſay ſo again I'll take you to jail along with her.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: I'll ſay it and prove it.

sp.speaker: Jailor.
sp.p: You will?

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: I will.

sp.speaker: Jailor.
sp.p: And ſo you ſhall, my lad; if you don't you ſhall ſee I'll prove you a fool preſently—lay hold of him.

sp.speaker: Conſtable.
sp.p: His worſhip's a knave, is he! and you'll prove it! a pretty fellow indeed!

sp.speaker: Jailor.
sp.p: If he does I'll be hang'd.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: You ſhall all be hang'd if I don't.

sp.speaker: Jailor.
sp.p: Aye, aye, who'll hang me, pray?

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: I will.

sp.speaker: Jailor.
sp.p: I'll give you leave to do that, my boy, when you pleaſe; but I fancy the gallows is groaning for you already.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: Hands off I ſay!

lg.head: SONG.
lg.l: Ye villains let me go,
Or ye too ſoon ſhall know,
I'll make ye glad to do it:
Ye blockheads let me paſs,
His worſhip is an aſs,
And I will make him rue it.

sp.speaker: Footman.
sp.p: What have ye got 'em again?

sp.speaker: Jailor.
sp.p: Aye part of 'em; and an impudent fellow here, who calls his worſhip a knave and an aſs.

sp.speaker: Footman.
sp.p: His worſhip an aſs! 'ſwounds he'll be hang'd?

sp.speaker: Jailor.
sp.p: I'll take care of that.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: You'd better take care of yourſelf.

sp.speaker: Jailor.
sp.p: Ne'er plague your head about that. What have you done with his worſhip? [to the Footman.]

sp.speaker: Footman.
sp.p:
He was tired to death, and went back again with ſome gentry we met, who
came from the lord knows where, to have a look at the wizzard.

sp.speaker: Jailor.
sp.p: They're come a day after the fair then: I wiſh we had got the old dog; it wou'd be a few pence in my pocket.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: That's very good; [aſide to Emma] Come, why don't you lead us to priſon? Why do you keep us both here?

sp.speaker: Jailor.
sp.p: You're in a hurry methinks: you're the ſtrangeſt hand I ever met with; but I'll oblige you for once; ſo come, come along. Conſtable you'd better hike after the old one, and take one or two along with you; then if you take him the prize will be your own you know.

sp.speaker: Robin.
sp.p:
Lud, what a dangerous thing it is to meddle with other folk's matters! mocking is catching, that ſaying is true enough: Sue and
I, forſooth, were only trying to make Allan a little jealous or ſo; but her kiſſes have ſtuck ſo cloſe to my lips, and her good natured looks, I am afraid have bewitched me. Now, as one may ſay, I find myſelf over head and ears in love: ratt'un, I don't know what to make on't; I wiſh I had not meddled with her: and yet ſomehow, I don't wiſh ſo neither: 'edad, an I thought ſhe cou'd love me, I ſhou'd be mainly pleas'd: I'll have a trial for her; I'm a little uneaſy about her too; and yet I'm ſtrangely pleas'd methinks—I'm moſt certainly in love, that's flat.—Sue has ſomething more than herſelf to give away too; old Quickſet, her father, has got a few good pounds by him I warrant me; and that is all Allan is in love with, in my opinion.

lg.l: I'm in love, lack a day! to be ſure,
I'm afraid I ſhall find it too true:
But where ſhall I find out a cure,
Except from a kiſs of dear Sue?
How Allan will laugh at me now!
I call'd him ſo often a fool:
And yet I can't help it I vow,
For I'm pinn'd like a dunce to my ſtool.

sp.p: 'Odds niggins, here they come together; I'll ſlip behind this buſh, and hear what they ſay.

sp.speaker: Allan.
sp.p: Why ſurely Sue, you cannot love Robin; if you do you are ſtrangely bit: he never lov'd a girl in his life, and always laugh'd at every body elſe that did: I'm ſure you only do it to plague me now.

sp.speaker: Sue.
sp.p: Nor you don't love Dolly Hedger to be ſure: don't think to deceive me Allan; ſhe has told me of all your tricks; you have juſt ſerved her as you have me; but you ſhall never deceive me again: love Robin indeed! if he was here I'd give him my hand before thy face.
sp.stage: [Robin runs between them; and takes Sue by the hand; Sue ſcreams out.

sp.speaker: Robin.
sp.p: I dad that's bravely ſaid; I'll take it, and thank thee to boot: I'm always ready to receive a good bargain, you ſee.

sp.speaker: Allan.
sp.p: Prithee make free with thy own, man.

sp.speaker: Robin.
sp.p:
Why ſo I do; ſhe ſaid ſhe'd be mine;
beſides, ſhe's none of your's, you never deſerved her.

sp.speaker: Allan.
sp.p: Don't I?

sp.speaker: Robin.
sp.p: No you don't; you've got twenty and deceive 'em all; and that girl is a fool that believes you, ſay what you will.

sp.speaker: Sue.
sp.p: He ſeems to be in earneſt! [aſide.]

sp.speaker: Allan.
sp.p: But ſay what you will, they will believe me.

sp.speaker: Sue.
sp.p: You're a conceited fool now for your pains; you ſhall find yourſelf miſtaken in me however, if there was not another man in the world.

sp.speaker: Robin.
sp.p: Eſpecially when there is another at hand that loves you ſo well.

sp.speaker: Allan.
sp.p: Now who wou'd deceive her?

sp.speaker: Robin.
sp.p: Why you if ſhe wou'd let you.

sp.speaker: Allan.
sp.p: You love her, hey?

sp.speaker: Robin
sp.p: Yes, I love her.

sp.speaker: Sue.
sp.p: Nay, Robin, now, I am ſure you deceive me.

sp.speaker: Robin.
sp.p: Murrins take me if I do.

sp.speaker: Sue.
sp.p: Nay now, you make me laugh: I never heard you talk of loving before.

sp.speaker: Allan.
sp.p: I ſhou'd like mainly to know what kind of love it wou'd be.

sp.speaker: Robin.
sp.p: Shou'd you? why I'd marry her directly, and make her a good huſband when I'd done; that is more than you can do in my opinion.

sp.speaker: Sue.
sp.p: Nay, Robin, don't joke too far.

lg.l: O I can ne'er believe
Another of your ſex;
You promiſe, to deceive,
You love but to perplex.
'Tis cruel and unkind,
To trifle, toy and play,
When all you've in your mind
Serves only to betray.

sp.speaker: Robin.
sp.p: Why look you Sue, I never lov'd a girl in my life before, I confeſs, and ſhou'd not have lov'd you now, in my opinion, had I not ſeen you ſo often made a fool of by another; and always knowing thee to be an honeſt, modeſt, good-natur'd laſs, I cou'd not help loving thee, ſomehow.

sp.speaker: Allan.
sp.p: Will you believe him Sue? ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Sue.
sp.p: I don't know what to ſay to it—I've a a good mind. [aſide.]

sp.speaker: Robin.
sp.p: She'll be a fool if ſhe believes thee any more however.

sp.speaker: Sue.
sp.p: You ſeem to be in earneſt methinks.

sp.speaker: Robin.
sp.p: An I be'ant I'll be hang'd: if you think you can love me, give me your hand, and you ſhan't doubt me any longer.

sp.speaker: Sue.
sp.p: Why, what wilt do man?

sp.speaker: Robin.
sp.p: Do! What I ought, to be ſure.

sp.speaker: Allan.
sp.p: What is that pray?

sp.speaker: Robin.
sp.p: What's that! why I'll tell you again and again: I'd take her to church directly, and not ſtand ſniv'ling and playing for a twelvemonth, and deceive her when I've done.—If ſhe'll give me her hand, you ſhall ſee if I don't.

sp.speaker: Sue.
sp.p: Then take it and welcome.

sp.speaker: Robin.
sp.p: Bleſſings on thee! that's kindly ſaid.

sp.speaker: Allan.
sp.p: Why, Sue, thou art not in earneſt ſure?

sp.speaker: Sue.
sp.p: Indeed but I am.

sp.speaker: Allan.
sp.p: Pſhaw, pſhaw, don't make a fool of one.

sp.speaker: Sue.
sp.p: You've made one of me long enough.

sp.speaker: Allan.
sp.p: But you won't marry him Sue?

sp.speaker: Robin.
sp.p: Aye, but ſhe will tho'.

lg.l: Come follow to church and you'll ſee,
I'll make her a wife
For the reſt of her life,
And ſhe a kind huſband of me.
At night when we merrily trip,
You may come to the wake,
And taſte the bride-cake,
But never more taſte of her lip.

sp.speaker: Allan.
sp.p: Odds heart what ſhall I do! who cou'd have thought it! I'm almoſt ready to hang myſelf.—If he marries her I'll make a cuckold of him, as ſure as he's born.

sp.speaker: Edwin.
sp.p:
Sure fate has doom'd me to inevitable deſtruction: every effort that I've made to
reſtore my liberty has unfortunately proved the means of making me ſtill more a priſoner: the ſtranger, my fair-ſpoken ally, is not yet return'd, and night is near at hand: Sightleſs, who never wanted ſpur to prick him on to cruelty, now will aggravate each circumſtance, which he thinks will reach my life.—Well, if my friend ſhou'd ne'er return again, I'm likely to be releas'd by death.

lg.l: Like one benighted and forlorn,
No guide to point my way,
Who wiſhes the return of morn,
Or Cynthia's ſilver ray.
With fear he ſteps and looks around,
At ev'ry tree retreats:
He trembles at each fancy'd ſound,
And ev'ry buſh he meets.
Shou'd fate have doom'd him to his end,
In vain for light he calls;
In vain he aſks for guide or friend,
When down the ſteep he falls.

div.head: SCENE X.
div.stage: Sightleſs's houſe, a tree with a bench before it.
Enter Sightleſs, Aethelia, Attendant and Forreſters.

sp.speaker: Sight.
sp.p: Here, fair lady, is my houſe, ſuch as it is: will you do me the honour to walk in and give me your good company? My wife is a little jealous, or ſo; but you need not mind that: pray walk in; it won't be long, I dare ſay, before we have our conjuring gentleman again.

sp.speaker: Aeth.
sp.p: I thank you, Sir, there's a pleaſant air abroad which is very agreeable; with your leave, I had much rather reſt me here a little. [ſits down on the bench.]

sp.speaker: Sight.
sp.p: By the by, I'm not ſorry for that neither: it may ſave me a ſupper perhaps. [aſide.] Why, as you ſay, Madam, it is very pleaſant to be ſure: this is a favourite tree of mine; I often make it my bench of authority, and try my criminals here.

sp.speaker: Aeth.
sp.p: Beneath this tree!

sp.speaker: Sight.
sp.p: Aye, marry do I: this tree was ſet by a grandfather of mine, and has had many a rebel hung upon it ſince he died; and if I ſhou'd once more meet with this wizard again, he ſhall have the honour of hanging upon it himſelf, and you ſhall have the pleaſure of ſeeing him, if you pleaſe: I am ſure you never ſaw a greater rogue hang'd in your life; and I've got another in priſon at preſent ſhall keep him company.

lg.l: I'll hang 'em, I'll hang 'em together,
And gibbet them both when I've done,
To be batter'd about with the weather,
And melted away with the ſun.
I'll hang 'em both here, I declare it,
With a fatal inſcription before 'em;
I'd have ev'ry mortal beware it,
And dread an high judge of the Quorum.

sp.speaker: Aeth.
sp.p: Sure you'll not hang him, Sir?

sp.speaker: Sight.
sp.p: Not burn him you mean! hang him! O yes, you may depend upon that.

sp.speaker: Aeth.
sp.p: What call you theſe, Sir?

sp.speaker: Sight.
sp.p: Some fool has got himſelf married I ſuppoſe; if he has got him as good a wife as mine, he had better ſtaid a little longer, and have been hang'd with Mr. Wizard and Co.
sp.stage: Enter Robin, Sue and others, dancing after the tabor and pipe acroſs the ſtage; they pull off their hats as they paſs.
sp.p: Away with ye, away with ye; you had need be merry forſooth: I hate to ſee ſuch a parcel of fools.

sp.speaker: Aeth.
sp.p: I muſt confeſs it gives me infinite pleaſure to ſee them ſo happy.

sp.speaker: Sight.
sp.p: Aye, but how will they look by and by? that's the joke.

sp.speaker: Aeth.
sp.p: That we cannot tell; a good heart ever makes a pleaſant eye.

sp.speaker: Sight.
sp.p: If that be true, your ladyſhip's a good heart of your own, for you have a main pleaſant eye, I can tell you that.

sp.speaker: Aeth.
sp.p: You've a pleaſant tongue of your own to tell me ſo; how true I will not ſay; nor will I thank you for the compliment, becauſe that wou'd be accepting of what I don't deſerve.

sp.speaker: Sight.
sp.p:
Troth but you do deſerve it; and
therefore muſt accept on't, and as a rarity too; for I ſeldom give my compliments away without return.

sp.speaker: Aeth.
sp.p: Then you ſell 'em, I preſume.

sp.speaker: Sight.
sp.p: No, no, lack a day, not I; when I compliment a lady, I mean to get a kiſs if I can, when a man—

sp.speaker: Aeth.
sp.p: His money I ſuppoſe?

sp.speaker: Sight.
sp.p: Hum, ah, why ſometimes, as one may ſay, on ſome occaſions or ſo: faith ſhe's a ſweet one! and as wiſe as a judge; ſhe'll be too much for me if I don't take care:—what a chance had I here now were I not married!—O plague on that bitter old jade at home I ſay, ſhe's a tough one, or the devil wou'd have had her ere now. [aſide.]

sp.speaker: Aeth.
sp.p: I wonder we have not ſeen my brother yet. [to her attendant.]

sp.speaker: Atten.
sp.p: It is very ſtrange!

sp.speaker: Sight.
sp.p: O here they come! here they come! now you ſhall ſee the very devil himſelf.

sp.speaker: Aeth.
sp.p: I ſhall beg to be excuſed the ſight.

sp.speaker: Sight.
sp.p: Don't fear, madam, don't fear; I've too much power over his devilſhip, than to let him do ſo ſweet a lady any harm.

sp.speaker: Aeth.
sp.p: I ſhall not fear that devil much that is afraid of you.

div.head: SCENE XI.
div.stage: Enter Henry and Emma, guarded by the Jailor, &c.

sp.speaker: Sight.
sp.p: So, madam Gad-about, you have found your way back again! but where is the ſon of old Beelzebub, the wizard?

sp.speaker: Jailor.
sp.p: And pleaſe your worſhip we have not ta'en him yet; maſter Conſtable and two or three more are after him: I ſuppoſe they will bring him anon: I thought it beſt to bring young madam back firſt, leſt ſhe might give us the ſlip again.

sp.speaker: Sight.
sp.p: Right, lad, right: but who have you here?

sp.speaker: Jailor.
sp.p: One of the wizard's acquaintance, I find: my lady and he were together.

sp.speaker: Sight.
sp.p: What is he? and where does he come from?

sp.speaker: Jailor.
sp.p:
I don't know, and pleaſe your worſhip; they were together, as I ſaid; and when
I talk'd of taking her away, he began to abuſe me, and call'd your worſhip a fool and an aſs.

sp.speaker: Sight.
sp.p: An aſs! an impudent raſcal! I'll aſs you ſirrah! I'll aſs you, ye villain, I will! you ſhall prove me an aſs or I'll prove you a gooſe.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: That your worſhip's an aſs needs no proof, or a goat rather.

sp.speaker: Sight.
sp.p: Sirrah! ſirrah! how dare you talk to me in this manner? doſt know who thou art talking to?

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: Perfectly well.

sp.speaker: Sight.
sp.p: Tie him neck and heels, an impudent ſcoundrel! and to priſon with him.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: Nay, give me leave to ſtrip firſt.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: Now, Sir, I'm at your ſervice: I was the wizard.

sp.speaker: Aeth.
sp.p: My brother! aſtoniſhment!

sp.speaker: Sight.
sp.p: Lord Henry!

sp.speaker: Emma.
sp.p: My Henry a lord!

sp.speaker: Sight.
sp.p: Mercy upon me! what will become of me?

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p:
Why don't you put your threats in practice Juſtice? where are your ropes and your gibbets? methinks your worſhip cools upon it:
what, not a word? ſhame on thee! well may'ſt thou ſtiffen with thy guilt! I cou'd forgive thy impriſonment and inſolence to me; but when I think on thy ungenerous and execrable behaviour to this lady, my temper catches fire at the deed, and whets me to revenge.

sp.speaker: Sight.
sp.p: Ah, your lordſhip! mercy! mercy! we are all frail.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: But not all villains too I hope, like thee: nay, be ever dumb: can there be excuſe for thee! old and full of ſin.—What would have been thy guilt, if fortune had not thrown me in the way to avert thy deſign, when like a monſter as thou art, thou threatenedſt to force this fair one to compliance: is it poſſible thou canſt form an excuſe for ſuch a crime? no, no, tho' her beauty's ſo divine, that ſaints beholding her might break off their prayers, and beg to taſte the perfume of her lips.—Come! come to my heart! thou matchleſs piece of fortitude and love! [embraces] with heaven's will and thine, we'll part no more.

sp.speaker: Emma.
sp.p: Nay, then let danger threaten as it liſts.

sp.speaker: Aeth.
sp.p: I'm all aſtoniſhment and wonder!

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p:
O ſiſter! take this jewel to thy breaſt;
for ſhe's a paragon of conſtancy: I've tried her truth, and, like the pureſt gold, have found her ſpeckleſs: ſhe has gone a pilgrimage for me by day and night, thro' all the perils of the dreary wild, and never faulter'd in a word or thought. Here, take her, Aethelia, for ſhe is one you long have wiſh'd to ſee:—behold the matchleſs Nut-brown Maid!

sp.speaker: Aeth.
sp.p: Indeed! then you could not have preſented me with a maid more welcome. [embraces her.]

sp.speaker: Emma.
sp.p: So kind a ſaying from ſo fair a friend, delights me much.

sp.speaker: Aeth.
sp.p: Tho' my expectations were other than I've met, I'm far more pleas'd in the diſappointment.

sp.speaker: Henry.
